She has been a [[List of members of the Riksdag|member]] of the [[Parliament of Sweden|Swedish Riksdag]] since 2006, and is currently deputy chairman in the [[Labour economics|committee on the labour market]] and spokesperson of labour market issues for the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party]]. == Biography == Ylva Johansson studied at [[Lund University]] and the [[Stockholm Institute of Education]] 1983-88 and 1991–92 and holds a [[Master of Science]] in education. In the [[Swedish parliamentary election, 1988|1988 general elections]] she was elected as a [[List of members of the Swedish Riksdag, 2006-2010|member]] of the [[Parliament of Sweden|Riksdag]] for the [[Left Party (Sweden)|Left Party - Communists]] (VPK). She later left the party and joined the Social Democrats. From 1992 to 1994 she worked as a teacher, until [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Prime Minister]] [[Ingvar Carlsson]] made her Minister for Schools in his government. In 1998, in a somewhat unusual [[News release|press release]], she and the then Minister for Finance [[Erik Åsbrink]] announced their wish to "publicly confirm that we are in love" and their intention to separate from their respective partners. Soon afterwards, Ylva Johansson left the government. The following years, she worked in the private sector. In 2004, Prime Minister [[Göran Persson]] appointed Ylva Johansson to the government in a new position, as Minister for Health and Elderly Care, succeeding [[Lars Engqvist]]. She has two children with her former husband [[Bo Hammar]] and a son with Erik Åsbrink. ==External links== *[http://www.sweden.gov.se/sb/d/4367 Ylva Johansson] - Information page on the Swedish Government web site *[http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/9809/23/ylva.html Regeringens heta romans] - Article in [[Aftonbladet]], September 23, 1998 on Ylva Johansson's and Erik Åsbrink's press release.
